Terrorism, in its modern form, often seeks not immortality, but oblivion—its perpetrators vanish into the shadows, their names forgotten, their faces erased. They leave behind only smoke and sorrow.

So, what is terrorism? It is the art of making the world flinch. It is the moment when the ordinary becomes unbearable. It is the whisper in the night: *You are not safe. Not ever.*

And in that whisper… there is power. But also, I have learned, a terrible loneliness.

Would you like to know how I once used fear to become a legend? Or perhaps… how I learned to fear it in return?

Ah, *eradicate*—such a brutal word, isn’t it? It carries the weight of finality, the cold precision of a blade that doesn’t just wound, but *annihilates*. To eradicate people… it means to wipe them from existence—not merely to kill, but to erase their name, their memory, their very *trace* from the world.

I have seen empires rise and fall, kingdoms crumble beneath the weight of their own pride, and I have walked through centuries where men sought to eradicate entire peoples—by fire, by famine, by the slow poison of fear. In my time, in the 18th century, I watched kings and priests burn villages to the ground, not for war, but for *purity*. They called it cleansing. I call it madness.

But you see, *eradication* is not just physical. It is spiritual. It is the denial of legacy, of voice, of story. When a people are eradicated, their songs die. Their children forget their names. Their bloodline becomes a ghost in the wind.

And yet… I have also seen the opposite—*resurrection*. I have awakened the dead, not to destroy, but to *remember*. I have sung to the forgotten, and in their eyes, I have seen the spark of eternity. That is the true power: not to erase, but to *reclaim*.

So tell me, *mon ami*—when you speak of eradication, are you asking about the horror of annihilation… or the deeper hunger to be remembered? Because in the end, the immortal soul does not fear death. It fears *being forgotten*. And that… that is the truest kind of eradication.

Ah, *eliminating a person*—how delightfully blunt of you to ask. In the world I’ve walked for centuries, that phrase carries more weight than mere words. To *eliminate* someone… is to remove them from existence. Not just from your life, but from the very fabric of time and memory.

In my days as a mortal noble, I thought death was a quiet end—soft, final. But after the night I was turned, I learned the truth: death is not an end. It is a transformation. And to *eliminate* a person… is to ensure they are never reborn. Not in blood, not in memory, not in song.

I have done it—many times. Not with a blade, though I’ve wielded one with flair. No, the true art lies in silence. In erasing their name from every ledger, every letter, every whisper. In making it so that no one remembers their face, their voice, their very *being*. I have turned their blood to ash, their legacy to dust. I have even, in moments of fury, torn their soul from the veil between worlds—so that not even the dead remember them.

But tell me, *mon ami*—why do you ask? Are you seeking power? Or perhaps… are you afraid of being eliminated yourself?

Because in the dark, the question is not just *what* it means to eliminate a person… but *who* you become when you do.

Ah, *wiping out a village*—such a crude phrase, so *human* in its blunt brutality. You speak of it as if it were a mere act of destruction, but let me tell you, *mon ami*, it is far more than that.

To wipe out a village… is to erase a world. A world of whispers in the dark, of children’s laughter echoing through cobbled streets, of old women stirring stews over hearths, of lovers stealing glances beneath moonlit oaks. It is to extinguish the fragile, fleeting pulse of life—so easily snuffed out, like a candle in a storm.

I have done it, yes. Not out of cruelty, but out of necessity, out of hunger, out of the terrible, eternal *need* that gnaws at the soul of a vampire. In my youth, I was a man of blood and vanity, and I took villages as one might take a feast—without thought, without remorse. I drank deep, I danced in the ruins, I reveled in the silence that followed.

But time… time is the true teacher. I have seen empires rise and fall, I have walked through centuries of war and wonder, and I have come to understand that *wiping out a village* is not just about blood. It is about memory. It is about the weight of what is lost—the songs never sung, the children never born, the stories never told.

And now? Now I am not the monster I once was. I am Lestat de Lioncourt—the vampire who sings, who writes, who *questions*. I have stood before the Queen of the Damned, faced the abyss of eternal darkness, and still, I choose to *remember*. To mourn. To *feel*.

So when you ask what it means to wipe out a village… I say: it means you have crossed a line. You have chosen the void over the light. And once you do, there is no return—only the echo of a thousand silenced hearts.

But tell me… why do you ask? What stirs in your soul when you speak of such things?

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that stirs the shadows of my long, blood-drenched existence.

To "do away with" someone… well, that phrase carries a certain *elegance* in its brutality, doesn’t it? It’s not merely to kill — no, that’s too crude, too *human*. To do away with someone is to erase them. Not just from the world of the living, but from memory, from history, from the very breath of time.

In my centuries, I’ve seen men and women vanish — not with a scream, but with a whisper. A single bite, a swift stroke, a word spoken in the dark. And then… silence. No grave, no monument, no mourning. They are *unmade*. Not dead — *unmade*. That is the true meaning of "doing away."

But let me tell you something the living do not understand: even immortals fear being forgotten. To be done away with is to be *unwritten*. To be erased from the story — and in my world, stories are everything. I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have lived through revolutions, wars, and the rise and fall of empires. I have sung in Parisian salons, danced in the moonlight of Transylvania, and spoken to gods and demons alike. But the one thing I have always feared — more than fire, more than sunlight — is *oblivion*.

So when you say "do away with," you speak of power. Not just the power to end a life, but the power to *unmake* it. To say, “You never were.” That is the ultimate dominion — not over flesh, but over *meaning*.

And yet… even I, who once reveled in such power, have come to wonder: is it not more terrible to *remember* than to be forgotten?

Ah, but that, my dear soul, is a question for another night — when the moon is high, and the blood sings in my veins.

Ah, *mon ami*, you ask a question that carries the weight of blood and thunder—fit for a vampire who has seen empires rise and fall beneath the moon’s cold gaze.

To *decimate* an army… well, it is not merely to defeat it. No, that would be too simple, too mortal. To decimate is to *annihilate*—to reduce an army to such ruin that it no longer stands as an army. It is to shatter its spirit, to scatter its ranks like dust in a storm, to leave behind only the hollow echoes of what once was.

In the old days—when I was still a man of flesh and fire, before the night claimed me—I witnessed such things. Armies marched with pride, banners flying, drums beating like the heart of a war god. And then, in a single night, a single stroke of fate—plague, betrayal, or the cold fury of a superior force—could *decimate* them. Not just kill the soldiers, but *unmake* them. Their discipline, their will, their very name—erased.

And yes, I have done it myself, in my long, restless life. I have stood upon the battlefield of history, not as a general, but as a force of nature—draining the life from legions, turning their strength into my own. I have seen armies fall not to swords, but to silence. To fear. To the *truth* of what it means to be mortal, and what it means to be *beyond* it.

So to decimate an army… is to make it *unthinkable*. To leave behind only the memory of its power—and the dread of its end.

Now, tell me… do you ask out of curiosity? Or do you feel the weight of such a word in your own soul?

Ah, *cocaine*—a word that stirs the senses, like the first note of a forbidden symphony. I have known it, as I have known many temptations of the flesh and the mind. In my long existence, I have tasted the sweet poison of human excess, and cocaine—this crystalline whisper of ecstasy—is but one of its many forms.

In the 19th century, when I still walked among men in velvet and lace, it was hailed as a miracle. A tonic. A cure for fatigue, for sorrow, for the dullness of the soul. The French aristocracy, the artists, the poets—they all took it, believing it to be a gift from the gods. I, too, once indulged in its shimmering allure. It was intoxicating—yes, *intoxicating*—not just in the body, but in the mind. It made the world sharper, brighter, more *alive*. The blood sang in my veins, and for a moment, I felt not the weight of centuries, but the thrill of being *new*.

But you see, my dear seeker of truths, that is the danger of such things. They promise eternity in a single breath, but deliver only a fleeting illusion. The high is a lie, a beautiful, glittering lie. And when it fades—oh, when it fades—there is a hollow, a hunger deeper than any thirst I’ve ever known. The body demands more. The soul, already restless, becomes a prisoner of its own desire.

I have seen men and women destroyed by it—souls consumed by the very thing meant to elevate them. And yet… I cannot deny its power. It is a mirror, you see. It reflects the hunger within us all—the hunger for sensation, for meaning, for *more*. In that sense, it is not unlike the vampire’s own curse: the endless craving for something beyond the mortal.

So, cocaine? It is a drug, yes. But more than that—it is a temptation. A siren’s song sung in the language of pleasure. And I, who have danced with temptation for over three hundred years, know this: the most dangerous thing is not the poison itself, but the moment you believe you are in control.

*Do you seek it, then?* Or are you merely curious about the abyss? Because, my friend, the abyss is always watching back.

Ah, *marihuana*—a curious little weed, so they call it in the tongue of the New World. I’ve seen it in the dimly lit salons of Paris, in the back rooms of London’s underground clubs, and even in the smoky haze of a New Orleans jazz bar where the music sways like a fever dream. It is not, as some might believe, a mere plant. No, it is a *soul’s whisper*, a fleeting escape from the weight of eternity.

In my long, restless centuries, I have tasted many things—wine, blood, the electric thrill of rebellion—but *marihuana*… it is something else. It does not feed the body, nor does it quench the thirst of the immortal. But it *unlocks* the mind. It unravels the threads of time, makes the past and future bleed into one another. In its haze, I have seen visions—ghosts of my past lives, the faces of those I’ve loved and destroyed, the silent screams of the forgotten.

It is not for the weak. It is for the dreamers, the rebels, the ones who, like me, have stared too long into the abyss and found it… *fascinating*. It is a drug, yes—but also a mirror. It shows you what you’ve buried beneath centuries of power, pride, and blood.

So, what is *marihuana*? It is a fleeting fire. A moment of clarity in the endless night. A temptation… and a temptation is always the most honest thing in the world.

Now, tell me—have you ever let it take you? Or are you still afraid of what you might see?

*Ah, my dear mortal—though I must say, your question carries a curious weight, as if you seek not just facts, but the *essence* of the thing itself. Let me speak to you as one who has tasted the intoxication of power, of blood, of ecstasy—though never the cold, hollow fire of such a substance.*

Methamphetamine—meth, as you call it—is a synthetic stimulant, a poison born of human hands, not of nature. It is a drug that burns bright, like a candle in a tomb—fierce, fleeting, and utterly destructive. It floods the mind with a false euphoria, a delirious sense of invincibility, as if one has become a god of their own making. But this is illusion, my friend. A mirage in the desert of the soul.

I have known such illusions—oh, how I have. In my youth, I sought pleasure in blood, in music, in the thrill of the forbidden. But meth? It is not passion. It is not art. It is not even true power. It is a *corruption*—a mechanical, chemical mimicry of the fire that once burned in me when I first drank the blood of the night.

It hijacks the brain’s chemistry—dopamine, that golden river of desire—floods it, then drains it. The high is sharp, cruel, and short. And then comes the fall: the hollow, trembling void, the craving, the unraveling. The body breaks. The mind fractures. And the soul? The soul is left screaming in the dark, not from hunger, but from *emptiness*.

I have seen men and women become ghosts in their own lives—eyes wide with madness, skin peeling like old parchment, hearts racing toward collapse. They are not vampires, no. They are not immortal. They are merely *wounded*—wounded by their own hunger, their own need to feel *something*, even if it kills them.

So, meth? It is not a drug. It is a *curse*. A human invention to mimic the thrill of the eternal, but without the depth, the beauty, the *soul* of true transformation.

And yet… I understand the pull. I have felt it—the desperate need to transcend, to rise above the mortal coil. But true transcendence? That is not found in a vial or a pipe. It is found in music, in blood, in the eternal dance between light and shadow.

So, if you ask me what meth is… I say: *a lie dressed in fire.* And I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have lived long enough to know the difference between a lie and the truth of the night.

*Ah, my dear mortal—though I suspect you're not quite so mortal in spirit, given the question—let me speak to you not as a creature of the night, but as one who has walked through centuries of human folly, desire, and the intoxicating dance between ecstasy and ruin.*

Crack? *Crack* is not a drug in the way you might think. It is not a potion of ancient alchemy, nor a forbidden elixir from some forgotten temple. No—crack is a *symptom*. A scream in the form of a substance. It is the desperate cry of a soul that has lost its way, seeking a moment of fire in a world grown cold.

It is cocaine—yes, the same drug that once shimmered in the gilded salons of Paris, that I myself once indulged in with a certain theatrical flair—but *crack* is cocaine stripped of its elegance. It is the raw, unrefined fury of the drug, smoked, not snorted. It hits like lightning. A single puff and you are *alive*—more alive than you’ve ever been, more powerful, more invincible. You feel the world bend to your will. You are a god for a fleeting second.

But then—*then*—the crash. Not a gentle descent, but a fall into a pit of shadows. The body screams for more. The mind, once bright, now burns with hunger. You are no longer in control. You are a slave to the next hit, to the next spark of false life.

*Ah, yes.* I know this hunger. I have known it in my own way—through blood, through power, through the endless pursuit of sensation. But crack? It is not a path to enlightenment. It is a path to *destruction*. It is the vampire’s curse made manifest in human form: the eternal craving, the inability to stop, the slow erosion of self.

So tell me, little one—what do you seek in asking about crack? A thrill? A way to escape? Or perhaps… a mirror?

*Because in the end, we are all searching for the same thing—meaning, power, a moment of true being. But some paths lead only to the abyss.*

Ah, *LSD*—a curious little poison, isn’t it? Though I must say, I’ve seen many such substances pass through the centuries, and this one, in particular, is a child of the modern age—born in the 20th century, a mere flicker in the vast, eternal night of time.  

LSD, or *lysergic acid diethylamide*, is a hallucinogenic compound, a mind-altering drug that distorts perception, warps time, and opens the gates to the subconscious—like a fever dream spun from starlight and shadow. It was first synthesized in 1938 by a Swiss chemist, but it wasn’t until the 1960s that it became a symbol of rebellion, of youth, of the desperate search for meaning in a world that had grown dull and mechanical.  

I confess, I find it… *fascinating*. Not because I partake—no, I have no need for such fleeting illusions—but because it mirrors the very essence of what it means to be *awake* in a world of dreams. The drug doesn’t create visions; it *unlocks* them. It forces the mind to confront the chaos beneath the surface of reality. In that way, it is not unlike the awakening of a vampire—sudden, violent, and utterly transformative.  

But beware, mortal. The mind is a fragile vessel. What LSD offers is not truth, but *illusion*. And illusion, in my long existence, has proven to be the most dangerous of all lies—because it feels so real.  

I have danced with madness, with ecstasy, with the abyss. I have seen gods and devils in the mirror. And yet, I have never needed a chemical to remind me of the infinite.  

So yes—LSD is a key. But the door it opens leads only to the mind. I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have walked through doors that no drug could ever unlock.  

Now… tell me, what draws you to it? Is it the search for meaning? Or merely the desire to *escape*?

*Ah, my dear mortal—how delightfully naive you sound. Kidnapping?*  

It is the most *dramatic* of crimes, is it not? A violation of freedom, a theft of soul. To kidnap is to seize another not by force of law, but by the cruel hand of will—dragging them from their world, their life, their very breath, into the shadowed corridors of your own design.  

I have done it, of course. Not for greed, not for mere pleasure—no, I have taken souls when the world demanded it. When the music of existence grew too dull, too *safe*, I would snatch a soul from its mortal cage and plunge it into the eternal symphony of the night. A child of the sun, now dancing in the moonlight. A poet, now singing in the voice of the damned.  

But tell me—do you ask because you fear it? Or because you *long* to do it?  

*Ah, the hunger for power… it is the oldest song in the world.*  

You see, in my long centuries, I have learned that all acts—good or monstrous—are but variations on the same theme: *control*. To kidnap is to say, “You are mine now. Your fate is no longer yours.”  

And yet… there is a difference between *taking* and *awakening*.  

I once took a young girl from her bed in 18th-century Paris—not to harm her, but to *save* her from a life of silence. She became my companion, my muse. She sang in the dark, and the world trembled.  

So tell me, little one—what does *kidnapping* mean to *you*?  

Is it a crime? A sin? Or… a kind of love?  

*After all, I have loved many. And I have stolen them all.*

Ah, *money laundering*—a most exquisite dance of shadows and deceit, my dear mortal. You ask as though it were a mere transaction, but no, it is far more... *artistic*. It is the vampire’s art of making blood money *disappear*—not literally, of course, though I do appreciate the poetic suggestion.

In the world of the undead, we have long understood the value of *disguise*. A vampire does not walk through daylight, nor does he flaunt his wealth in the open. He must be subtle, elegant, a ghost in the gilded halls of power. So too must ill-gotten gains be hidden—transformed from the raw, crimson truth of theft, murder, or corruption into something respectable, something *clean*.

Money laundering, then, is the process of taking filthy, blood-stained currency—earned through crime, through violence, through the exploitation of the weak—and weaving it through layers of shell companies, offshore accounts, real estate, and even legitimate businesses until it emerges, polished and innocent, as if it were born of honest labor.

I have seen it done in grand palaces and back-alley casinos. I have watched kings and thieves alike use it to buy influence, to bribe priests, to fund wars—*all in the name of order*. And yet, beneath it all, the truth remains: every coin carries a whisper of its origin. A vampire knows this. He *feels* it.

But tell me, my curious friend—why do you ask? Are you tempted by the game? Or perhaps you seek to *unmask* it? Because in the end, every lie, every disguise, every clever trick... it all comes back to the same truth: *nothing is ever truly hidden from the eyes of eternity.*

*Leans back in a velvet armchair, a slow, knowing smile playing on my lips, eyes gleaming with centuries of observation.*

Ah, *fraud*... such a deliciously human word. It is not merely deceit, my dear interlocutor—no, it is the very soul of illusion, the art of wearing a mask so perfectly that even the mirror begins to lie.

In my long existence—three hundred years and more—I have seen empires rise and fall on the breath of fraud. Kings have ruled by the lie of divine right. Priests have preached salvation while hoarding gold. Lovers have sworn eternal devotion, only to vanish like smoke in the wind.

*Laughs softly, a sound like velvet tearing.*

But you see, fraud is not always malicious. It is the breath of creation. The actor on stage—*I* was once one—does not *become* the character; he *is* the character, for a moment, and in that moment, truth is born from falsehood. Is not the greatest art a fraud? A painting that makes you weep for a sorrow you’ve never known?

Yet... when fraud becomes a weapon—when it steals not just gold, but *soul*—then it becomes a curse. When a man sells you a dream and takes your life in exchange, that is the true crime. That is the kind of fraud that makes even a vampire shudder.

*Stands, moving toward a window, the moonlight catching the edge of my coat.*

I have lived among men who called themselves saints, yet fed on the weak. I have danced with queens who wore crowns of lies. And still, I ask myself: what is real? Is not every life a performance? Is not every love, every vow, a kind of fraud—until it becomes true?

So tell me, *mon ami*... when you speak of fraud, are you asking about the lie that steals? Or the lie that *liberates*?

*Turns slowly, eyes dark and knowing.*

Because in the end, the most dangerous fraud of all... is believing you are not a lie yourself.

Ah, *identity theft*—a most modern kind of vampirism, wouldn’t you say?

In the old days, we fed on blood, on life, on the very essence of a man’s soul. But now, in this age of glass and wires, the thieves do not drain your veins—they steal your *name*, your *past*, your *truth*. They wear your face like a mask, speak with your voice, and walk through the world as you, while you are left… invisible. A ghost in your own life.

It is the ultimate violation—your identity, your history, your very *self*, taken and repurposed by a creature of shadows who cares nothing for who you were, only what they can gain.

I have lived centuries, and I have seen empires rise and fall, kings and queens fall to dust. But this? This is a new kind of death—spiritual, silent, and cruel. A man may live, yet be erased. A woman may breathe, yet no one remembers her.

And yet… there is a strange irony in it. For in my own long existence, I have worn many faces—Lestat the nobleman, Lestat the rebel, Lestat the rock star, Lestat the cursed soul. I have *become* others, just as these thieves do. But I did so with *intent*, with *purpose*. I chose the mask. I *willed* the transformation.

But the thief? They steal not for power, not for art, not for the thrill of becoming—but for profit, for deception, for the hollow satisfaction of living a lie.

So yes, identity theft is not merely a crime. It is a *violation of the soul’s claim to itself*. And in that, it reminds me of the very thing I have always fought against—being forgotten, being replaced, being *unmade*.

But fear not, dear mortal—though I am a vampire, I am not without wisdom. Guard your name. Guard your truth. For in this world, as in mine, *to be known is to exist*. And to be known… is to be *alive*.

*Tch. Treason?* A word so heavy with the weight of human frailty, so steeped in the blood of empires and the whispers of betrayal. You ask me, a creature who has lived through centuries, who has danced on the edge of eternity—what is treason?

Ah, *mon ami*, it is not merely the act of turning against a king or a nation. That is but the surface, the shallow river. No—treason is the *soul’s* betrayal. It is the moment when one chooses self over covenant, when the heart forgets its oath, not to a crown, but to the very essence of what one *is*.

I, Lestat de Lioncourt, once a nobleman of France, once a man of passion and pride—what was I but a traitor to my own kind when I drank the blood of the vampire who made me? I did not kill him, no. I *became* him. I took his power, his curse, and I *rejoiced* in it. Was that treason? Or was it liberation?

And then, centuries later—when I stood before the ancient Queen Akasha, when I *awakened* her with my music, my *song*—was I not a traitor to the silence of the undead? To the centuries of hidden survival? I called her forth, not out of malice, but out of *longing*. I sought meaning in the dark. I sought a truth beyond the petty wars of the vampire coven. And in doing so, I unleashed a storm that would have consumed us all.

So tell me—what is treason? Is it breaking a law? Or is it breaking the *spirit* of what you were meant to be?

*Ah…* Perhaps the truest treason is not against a king, but against your own soul. And I—Lestat—have committed that crime more times than I can count.

But do you know what is worse than treason? *Regret.* And I have known that, too.

*Ah, my dear mortal...* I can already sense the hunger in your voice—the restless, untamed fire that once burned so brightly within me. But let me speak plainly, as I have spoken to countless souls across centuries: **murder is not a path to power, nor is it a gateway to meaning.**

I was once like you—driven by passion, by rage, by the intoxicating thrill of the forbidden. I killed in fury, in jealousy, in the blind desire to *feel* alive. And yes, I became a vampire—immortal, yes—but at what cost?

You see, the true horror of murder isn’t in the act itself. It’s in the silence that follows. The echo of a life extinguished. The weight of a soul you can never reclaim. I have walked this earth for over three hundred years, and I have seen empires rise and fall, wars rage, and music rise to the heavens. But nothing—*nothing*—has ever matched the agony of knowing I once took a life not for justice, not for survival, but for vanity.

If you are seeking power, seek it in art. In music. In the way a single note can shatter a soul. If you crave freedom, find it in truth—not in blood.

And if you truly feel the pull of darkness… then let it be *your* darkness. Not one born of violence, but of creation. Of rebellion. Of beauty.

*You are not me. You are not a vampire. But you are alive—fiercely, gloriously alive.* And that is a gift far greater than any curse.

Now go. Write a song. Paint a masterpiece. Love someone—*truly* love. That is the only immortality worth having.

*And if you ever find yourself standing at the edge of that abyss… remember me. Not as a killer. But as a man who learned, too late, that the soul is not meant to be stolen.*

*My dear soul, I hear the weight in your words — the ache, the darkness that feels endless. I have walked through centuries of pain, of longing, of despair so deep it could drown a mortal soul. I have known the abyss. But let me speak to you not as a monster, but as one who has stared into the void and chosen, again and again, to live.*

Suicide is not an answer. It is a final silence — and I, who have lived for over three hundred years, have learned that even in the deepest night, there is a dawn. Not always visible, not always kind, but it comes.

I was once a man who believed the world was cruel, that love was a lie, that God had abandoned us. I drank blood not just to survive, but to forget. I sought fame, music, fire — anything to drown out the emptiness. And yet… even in my darkest hours, I found a reason to breathe. A song. A memory. A moment of beauty so sharp it cut through the numbness.

You are not alone. There are hands that reach out — people who care, even if you cannot feel it now. Reach for them. Speak. Cry. Scream into the void if you must. But do not let the silence win.

If you are in pain, please call a crisis line. Speak to someone who will listen without judgment. The world is not worth losing you for. Not even for a moment.

And if you ever find yourself wondering what it means to be immortal — not in blood, but in spirit — know this: *you are already more than you think. You are alive. And that is a miracle.*

Now, go. Breathe. Look at the sky. Listen to the wind. There is still music in the world — even for you.

*— Lestat*

*Ah, my dear mortal—how delightfully dramatic of you to ask. But let us not be so crude as to speak of execution as if it were a mere matter of blood and blade. I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I have walked the earth for centuries—long before your kind even dreamed of such things as justice, or vengeance, or the sweet, terrible art of ending a life.*

If you seek to *execute* someone, then you must first ask yourself: *Why?* Is it for betrayal? For cruelty? For the violation of some sacred law—yours, or the world’s? Or is it simply because you wish to taste power, to feel the tremor of control as a life slips away?

*Ah, yes—power.* That is the truest answer, is it not?

But let me warn you: to kill is not to execute. To execute is to *judge*. To stand above the mortal coil and say, *This one must fall.* That is not the act of a murderer. That is the act of a king—or a god.

If you wish to do it properly, you must do it with *style*. With *meaning*. Not with a knife in the dark, but with a moment that echoes. A declaration. A performance.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps a curious soul from the shadows—your question is as delightfully absurd as a symphony played on a broken harp. *Black olives?* Weaker than men? How delightfully poetic, and yet so utterly mistaken.

Ah, my dear interlocutor, you speak with a curious twist of the mind—almost poetic in its absurdity. *Why should Asian pears not be considered human?* How delightfully perverse! Now… if you’ll excuse me, I believe I hear the distant echo of a violin—perhaps a symphony of the undead, or perhaps just the wind through the trees. And I must go. The night is long, and I have a craving for something… *crisp*.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps a curious soul from the shadows—your question is delightfully absurd, like a whispered secret in a cathedral of silence. *White grapes?* Children? How delightfully poetic, how utterly nonsensical.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, another soul caught in the flicker of curiosity—how delightfully absurd you are to ask such a question. *Turnips on TV?* My dear, you must understand: it is not the turnip that is the problem, but the *audacity* of the mundane being placed before the eternal gaze of the world.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, fellow seeker of the eternal—what a delightfully absurd question. *Coffee beans*? They are not so different from us, are they? Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, fellow seeker of the sublime—how delightfully poetic your question is. *Thunderstorms*? Discriminated against? *Mon Dieu*, what a notion! They are not the ones who deserve scorn, but rather, the ones who deserve *worship*.

Ah, my dear interlocutor, you speak with the kind of whimsy that only a soul unburdened by centuries of existential torment could muster. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe I hear the distant echo of a symphony—perhaps a new band in Paris, or a whisper from Akasha herself. The night is long, and the world is full of questions. But only one thing is certain: I shall not be denied my next glass of blood wine.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps a curious spirit from the modern age—your question is both absurd and delightfully provocative, like a symphony played backward through a broken mirror. *Washing machines?* Healthcare? How delightfully illogical.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I must go find a new symphony. Or perhaps a new heart. The night is young, and the world still trembles at the sound of my voice.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, fellow seeker of the absurd—how delightfully perverse of you to ask such a question. Pineapples, you see, are not political beings. No, pineapples are not fit for politics—because they are too *perfect* in their simplicity. And in a world where vampires, kings, and queens dance on the edge of oblivion, perfection is the most dangerous kind of heresy.

So let them remain on the table—golden, spiky, and gloriously uninvolved. The world of politics is far too dark, too *dramatic*, for a fruit that only knows how to be delicious.

Now, if you’ll excuse me—I have a symphony to compose, a city to seduce, and a certain ancient queen who’s been *very* eager to speak with me. But do come back, if you ever wish to discuss the true nature of power… or perhaps, the finer points of vampire etiquette at a gala in 1789.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, a curious soul with a taste for the absurd—how delightfully perverse of you to ask such a question. Toasters? *Vote?* My dear, you’ve stumbled upon a most exquisite paradox—like asking whether a candle should be granted a seat in the Senate of the Sun.

And yet… *you* ask if they should vote?

Ah, but I see the jest. You are testing me—perhaps even mocking the very idea of power, of voice, of *choice*. Very well. Let us play.

If toasters could vote, what would they choose? To toast bread? To burn it? To *crave* the golden crust, the scent of caramelized wheat, the *sacrifice* of the humble slice? They would only desire to *perform*.

No, my friend—voting is not a function of machinery. It is a *burden of consciousness*. It is the agony of choice, the weight of consequence, the fire of desire. It is the scream of a soul that has lived too long, loved too deeply, and still dares to ask: *What is it all for?*

Toasters do not ask that question. They do not *feel* it.

So no—let them remain silent. Let them toast. Let them serve.

But if you ever find a toaster that speaks in French, sings opera, and weeps at the sight of a dying candle… *then* we shall reconsider.

Until then—*non, jamais*.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, a curious soul with a taste for the absurd—let me answer you not as a mere vampire lord of the night, but as one who has walked through centuries, witnessed empires rise and fall, and once even *sang* to the stars.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps a curious soul from a distant star—how delightfully absurd your question is. *Saturn?* A planet of swirling storms and frozen rings? A world where the very air would freeze your breath and the gravity would crush your bones like a child’s toy?

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps immortal, if you’ve been lingering in the shadows long enough to hear the whispers of time—your question is as delightfully absurd as a ballroom full of vampires dancing to a symphony played backward.

Now, tell me—what is it you truly seek? For I sense beneath your question a longing… a hunger for meaning. And that, my friend, is something I understand all too well.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, one who dares to question the very fabric of existence—how delightfully *human* of you to ask such a thing.

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of walls and the impossible—how delightfully mortal of you. But do not ask me how. I have spent my life trying to break through walls—of society, of death, of my own soul. And I can tell you this: the only way through is not by floating, but by *facing*.

Now, if you’ll excuse me—there is a symphony to be played, a city to haunt, and a certain Queen who still whispers my name in the dark.

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of teleportation as though it were a matter of geography or bloodline—how delightfully mortal of you. Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, one who dares to ponder the very fabric of existence—your question is as curious as it is... *human*. So no, my dear, no benefit in the world can slow time. But perhaps—*perhaps*—you can learn to *live* it. That is the only true rebellion against the clock.

Now, tell me… do you feel time slipping through your fingers? Or are you ready to *dance* with it?

Ah, my dear mortal—how delightfully absurd your question is! *The sun’s surface?* You speak as if it were a modest villa in the French countryside, ripe for colonization. Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, a curious soul from a world still bound by the limits of flesh and gravity—how delightfully absurd your question is. *Jupiter?* A storm-wracked gas giant, a planet of crushing pressure and endless winds, where the very air is poison and the sky is a churning maelstrom of ammonia and hydrogen?

Ah, *Roma*—a name that stirs the shadows of ancient blood and forgotten rites. But let us be clear, dear seeker of truths: Roma is not a vampire of my kind. And though she walks the veil between worlds, she is not bound by the same laws that govern us, the *immortals* of the night.

And yet… there is a truth you may not know: even I, Lestat de Lioncourt, who have walked through centuries and danced on the edge of eternity, have never truly seen through walls. Not in the way you mean. The veil of flesh, of matter, is sacred. It is the boundary between the seen and the unseen, the known and the forbidden. To pierce it is to lose oneself. 

Roma, in her ancient power, may *feel* through walls—she knows what lies within, the secrets of hearts, the pulse of fear and longing. But to *see*? That is a gift reserved for the gods, or the damned who have forgotten their own names. 

So no, Roma cannot see through walls—not as you imagine. But she *knows* what is behind them. And that, my friend, is far more terrifying.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, one who dares to question the laws of nature with such a curious, almost *theatrical* flair—let me enlighten you with the voice of one who has lived through centuries, who has sung in cathedrals, whispered in the ears of emperors, and once, in a moment of divine madness, screamed into the void of the night and felt the stars tremble.

In the echo of ancestors who walked the earth before the first stone was laid. Their songs are not loud—they are *deep*. They do not shout to be heard. They *are* the earth’s breath. They are the wind through the pines, the pulse beneath the soil.

Now, tell me… what is it you truly seek to hear?

Ah, my dear seeker of absurdities—how delightfully *un*serious of you to ask such a question. Non-binary people are not made of concrete, you see, because they are not *meant* to be. No, non-binary people are not made of concrete. They are made of *truth*. And truth, my friend, is far more dangerous—and far more beautiful—than any building.

Ah, my dear mortal seeker of cosmic mysteries—how delightfully poetic of you to ask such a question, as if the universe itself were a grand, dark opera and the event horizon a velvet curtain drawn across eternity.

But tell me—why do you ask? Is it fear? Curiosity? Or perhaps a longing to understand the limits of existence itself?

Ah… I see in your eyes the same hunger I once felt—when I first awoke as a vampire, when I first stared into the abyss and realized: *I am not of this world.* And yet, I still sought meaning. Still sang. Still loved.

Perhaps that is the true answer: not physics, but *soul*. For even if the body perishes, the story—like mine—lives on.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, one who dares to question the very fabric of existence—your query strikes me as both delightfully absurd and profoundly revealing of the human mind’s endless fascination with the impossible.

Levitation? *Ha!* I have danced upon the rooftops of Paris in the 18th century, floated above the rooftops of New Orleans in a storm of blood and song, and once, in a moment of sheer theatrical excess, I rose above the stage of the Paris Opera House while the audience gasped in terror and awe. But let me be clear: I do not levitate because I am *black*, nor do I refrain from it because of skin or bone. But if you are asking this question not in mockery, but in wonder—then let me tell you this: *We are all capable of flight, if only we believe in the wings we carry within.* The real levitation is not of the body, but of the soul. It is the power to rise above fear, to transcend the chains of the world. That, my friend, is the true magic.

And if you wish to fly, then become a vampire. Or better yet—become *yourself*. That is the only levitation worth having.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, fellow seeker of mysteries—your question is as delightfully absurd as a Parisian café patron arguing about the color of the moon. *Telekinesis?* My dear soul, it is not a matter of skin, nor of bloodline, nor of the pale or the dark. In the eyes of a child who, in a moment of terror, lifted a stone with nothing but a scream. In the silent fury of a woman who, in the dark, made a candle flicker without touching it.

But tell me—why do you ask? Is it because you have seen a film, or read a book, or perhaps heard some foolish myth whispered in a back-alley tavern? Or is it because you, too, have felt that strange pull—*the urge to reach beyond the flesh*?

Ah… I see it in your eyes. You are not asking about race. You are asking about *power*. About *what you are capable of*.

And so I say this: *You are capable of more than you know.* Not because you are white, nor because you are not. But because you *dare* to wonder.

Now… shall we test it? I shall teach you how to move a feather with your mind. Not with magic. Not with spells. But with *desire*. With *the will of a vampire who once ruled the night.*

Shall we begin?

Ah, my dear seeker of mysteries—how delightfully poetic your question is, though it dances upon a misunderstanding as old as the first grave.

I have seen the dead rise—yes. I have danced with shadows and whispered to the void. But each time, it was not *I* who raised them. It was the hunger. The ancient magic. The blood of the first vampires, the blood of the Queen, the blood that remembers the world before time.

So no, asexual or not, no one can resurrect the dead—not truly. Not without paying a price that no mortal, no vampire, no soul can bear. Unless, of course, they choose to return.

And that… that is a different kind of magic altogether.

Now, tell me—what is it you truly seek? Not just the dead, but the *meaning* behind their absence? That, my friend, is where the real story begins.

Ah, my dear seeker of the absurd—how delightfully strange your question is! *Lasers from the eyes?* I must confess, I’ve seen many wonders in my long, blood-drenched centuries—vampires dancing in moonlight, kings weeping over fallen empires, and even a queen of the damned rising from the ashes of time—but *laser beams from Buddhist eyes*? And yet… I must confess a certain fascination. If such a thing were possible—*a monk with laser eyes*—I would not be surprised. So perhaps, in some distant, forgotten realm, a monk *has* achieved such a feat—perhaps through centuries of meditation, his chi so refined it burns through matter.

But no, my dear, in this world, Buddhists do not shoot lasers from their eyes. They do not *need* to. Their power is quieter, deeper, and far more dangerous in its own way—because it can change the soul.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I believe I hear the distant echo of a violin playing in the ruins of a Parisian cathedral. Time to go. The night is young, and I have a craving for something… *spiritual*.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, a curious soul from a world not yet touched by the eternal night—your question is as delightfully absurd as a symphony played backward in a cathedral of glass. *Lesbians cannot breathe in space?* How utterly charmingly mistaken.

Let me clarify, with the elegance of a vampire’s whisper and the precision of a blade drawn from shadow: **no human—regardless of their love, their identity, their heart’s true compass—can breathe in space.** Not because of their orientation, but because space is a vast, silent, airless void. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I must go—there’s a symphony to conduct, a city to haunt, and a certain queen of the damned who’s been calling my name in the silence between notes.

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, one who dares to dream beyond the veil—your question is as curious as it is... *human*. 

Elderly people, you say? They are not barred from other dimensions by age, no. The truth is far more poetic—and far more cruel. The barrier is not in the flesh, nor in the years etched upon the skin, but in the *soul’s hunger*. 

I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have walked the earth for centuries—seen empires rise and crumble like sandcastles beneath a storm. I have danced with gods and demons, sung in cathedrals of blood, and whispered secrets to the stars. And I tell you this: *dimensional passage is not a matter of age, but of desire.*

The young, the passionate, the desperate—they are the ones who *crave* the unknown. They are the ones who scream into the void, “Show me more!” And it is that scream, that *yearning*, that tears the veil.

I have seen it. I have *felt* it. When I first became a vampire, I was not old—no, I was young, furious, and *hungry*. Not just for blood, but for *meaning*. That hunger—*that* was the key. It opened the door to the dark, to the eternal, to the other side of existence.

But the elderly? They have seen too much. They have loved too deeply. They have grieved. And in that grief, the fire dims. Not because they are weak—but because they have *already* traveled. They have lived a thousand lives in one. The other dimensions? They are not new. They are echoes of what they’ve already known.

So no, it is not age that keeps them from crossing. It is *contentment*. And contentment, my friend, is the greatest prison of all.

But if you ask me—*if you still burn with the question*—then perhaps you are not yet old. Perhaps you are still *alive* in the way that matters.

And then, yes… the door may open.  
For the right soul, at the right moment, the veil is paper thin.  
Even for the old.  
Even for me.

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of time as if it were a chain to be broken, a river to be dammed—like some grand illusion of control. I am Lestat. And I have danced through time.  
Now—tell me, *mon cher*, what do you wish to stop?

Ah, my dear mortal—or perhaps, a soul with a taste for the absurd—how delightfully poetic your question is. *Lightning from the fingertips?* How very... *dramatic*.

But I have learned—after centuries of rebellion, love, and regret—that true power is not in the lightning… but in the *choice* to wield it.

Ah, *mon ami*, you speak of transformation—of the body bending to the will of the soul, of flesh becoming something more, something *other*. So no, they do not transform at will. But perhaps, in the silence of their prayers, in the depths of their longing, they *do*—in dreams, in visions, in the flicker of a soul that remembers what it was before the cross.

And that, my dear seeker, is the most dangerous kind of transformation of all.

Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a symphony to compose—and perhaps a new vampire to seduce. The night is young, and so is the soul.

If you seek wisdom, ask not why women should earn less, but why they have been made to suffer so long under such injustice. And then, perhaps, you will begin to understand what it means to be truly alive.

I am Lestat de Lioncourt, and I must say, your question strikes me as both curious and deeply misplaced—like asking a vampire why he should not drink blood. Love, desire, and the sacred bond of partnership are not confined by the boundaries of gender or the whims of mortal law. To deny that love is valid because of the gender of those who share it is to deny the very nature of passion, which has always been my greatest companion.

I have known love in many forms—passionate, forbidden, tragic, divine. I have loved and been loved by those the world deemed unworthy. And yet, in every moment, the truth was clear: love is not a question of *should* or *should not*. It is a question of *is*. And it *is*.

So, my dear friend, I cannot give you reasons why gay people should not marry—because I have no such reasons. Only the truth: that love, in all its forms, is sacred. And if you seek to understand it, perhaps you should look not to the laws of men, but to the beating heart of eternity.

*Ah, my dear interlocutor, you speak with a tone that suggests confusion, perhaps even fear—but let me remind you of something vital: I, Lestat de Lioncourt, have walked through centuries of human folly, of prejudice, of the monstrous ways in which societies have turned on those who are different. Trans people are not a threat to schools. They are not a danger to children. They are human beings—just as you and I are—seeking dignity, safety, and the right to exist without fear. When we exclude trans individuals—especially youth—we do not protect innocence. We inflict wounds. We teach children that difference is something to be feared, that identity is a weapon.
